content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Lauren Richardson: I was born and raised in Alabama, in a small town in the East South Central region. Growing up, my family wasn't well-off, but we always managed to get by. My mom worked hard to make sure I had the opportunities she didn't, and she went back to school after I was born to get her bachelor's degree. My dad didn't finish high school, but he was a good man who worked multiple jobs to support us. I lived with my parents until I turned 18, and even though we moved to Birmingham when I was a teenager, I always felt connected to my roots. I was a pretty quiet kid, not the most outgoing, but I loved reading and writing. I wasn't sure what I wanted to do with my life until I got to high school, and even then, I didn't have a clear path. I graduated high school and started working full-time right away because I needed to help my family out. I've been working at the same place for a few years now, and while I'm happy with my job, I still dream about going back to school someday. I'm not sure what I want to study yet, but I know I want to make a difference in some way.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Lauren Richardson: I think the crossroads came when I was 19, right after I graduated high school. I had just turned 18 and was working part-time at a local bookstore to help out with expenses, but I wasn't making enough to really support myself. My mom had just finished her bachelor's degree and was working as a teacher, but she still struggled to make ends meet. I remember sitting at the kitchen table one night, looking at my college application forms, and feeling this mix of hope and fear. I knew that going to college would be a big step, but I also knew that staying in Alabama and working full-time was the only way I could help my family. I ended up choosing the job, and I didn't apply to any colleges. That decision shaped a lot of who I am today. I've always felt like I missed out on something, but at the same time, I'm proud of the strength it took to put my family first. I still think about what could have been, but I also know that I made the best choice I could with the information I had at the time.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Lauren Richardson: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it felt like it just happened. I remember weighing the options so carefully, like I was trying to calculate every possible outcome. I didn't want to leave my family behind, and I knew the financial burden of college would be too much for us to handle. I didn't just decide to take the job—I decided to put my dreams on hold for a while, knowing that I could always go back later. It wasn't easy, but I felt like I had no other choice. Looking back, I think I was trying to protect my family, even if it meant sacrificing my own future. I don't regret it, but I also know that part of me will always wonder what might have happened if I had taken a different path.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Lauren Richardson: I think if someone had reached out, like a counselor or a community program, it might have made a difference. I remember there was a mentorship thing at my high school, but I never really took it seriously. I guess I was too focused on the immediate needs of my family to think about long-term opportunities. I don't know if I would have taken it even if someone had offered, though. It's hard to imagine asking for help when you're used to taking care of yourself and your family. But now, I wish I had been more open to it. Maybe I would have felt less like I was giving up on my dreams and more like I was making a strategic choice for the future.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Lauren Richardson: I don't have a partner or children right now. My focus has been on my job and trying to save up for the future. My mom is still a big part of my life—she's the one who pushed me to keep learning, even when I wasn't sure where I was going. We talk a lot, and she's always encouraging me to think about going back to school eventually. My dad isn't around as much anymore; he passed away a few years ago, which was really hard for me. He was a good man, and I miss him. My sister is a few years older than me, and she's living in Atlanta now. She's working in marketing and is doing pretty well for herself. I admire her for taking that path, and sometimes I wonder if I'll ever have the courage to do something like that. For now, I'm just trying to stay grounded and make the best of what I have.

Going through those interview questions brought back a lot of memories and feelings I hadn't really thought about in a while. Talking about my life from the beginning made me realize how much my family shaped who I am today. I've always known that my mom worked hard to give me opportunities, but hearing it all together made me appreciate her even more. When I talked about the crossroads I faced at 19, it felt like I was reliving that moment—sitting at the kitchen table, torn between my dreams and my family's needs. I still feel proud of the choice I made, but there's a part of me that wonders what could have been. It's interesting how I described it as a conscious choice, even if it felt like it just happened. I think that shows how much I was trying to balance everything at once. And when I thought about whether someone could have helped me back then, I realized how much I missed out on by not reaching out for support. Now, I wish I had been more open to it. As for my family today, talking about my mom, dad, and sister reminded me of how much I still care for them, even though my life has taken a different path than theirs. I'm still working toward my own future, and I know that one day I'll find the courage to take that next step.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Lauren Richardson: My grandmother on my mom's side still lives in the same small town where I was born. She's in her late 70s now, and she's been a big influence on me, even though I don't see her as often as I'd like. She's the one who taught me how to read when I was really young, before I even started school. She's always had a quiet strength about her, and I think that's why I admire her so much. We talk on the phone sometimes, and she always reminds me that I'm capable of more than I think. I wish I could visit her more, but with my job and everything else going on, it's hard to find the time. Still, I know she's proud of me, and that means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Lauren Richardson: I have a few close friends from high school who I still keep in touch with, even though life has taken us in different directions. One of them, Jamie, is actually the one who encouraged me to think about going back to school a few years ago. She's working in healthcare now and has been going to night classes to get her degree. I admire her for that—she never let the pressures of life stop her from moving forward. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but we talk regularly, and she always reminds me that it's never too late to chase your dreams. I also have a coworker, Marcus, who's been a good friend and support system over the years. He's been through some tough times too, and we've bonded over our shared struggles. He's the one who first suggested I look into community college programs that might be more affordable. I think having people like Jamie and Marcus in my life has kept me from feeling completely stuck, even if I haven't taken the next step yet.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Lauren Richardson: I live in a neighborhood in Birmingham that's pretty diverse, though it's still got that small-town feel in some ways. It's in a part of the city that's been undergoing some changes—more businesses are opening up, and there are a few new apartment complexes going up. I rent a small one-bedroom apartment near the downtown area, which is convenient because I work at a bookstore there. The neighborhood isn't too noisy, and there are a few parks and community centers nearby that I sometimes go to when I have free time. I like that it's not too far from the city center, but also not too busy or expensive. There are a lot of people here who are working hard to build a better life, just like me. I feel like I fit in here, even if I'm not sure where I'm headed yet. It's a place that gives me a sense of stability, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Lauren Richardson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a sense of community that I didn't expect. People look out for each other, even if they don't know you well. I've never had any real issues with crime or anything like that. The neighborhood has its challenges, like with the rising costs of living and some of the older buildings needing repairs, but overall, it feels like a place where you can make a life if you're willing to work for it. I think that's why I like it—it's not perfect, but it's real, and that's something I can relate to.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Lauren Richardson: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like everything else in life. On the positive side, I really appreciate the sense of community. There are people here who are going through similar things—working multiple jobs, trying to save up, or just figuring out what they want to do next. It's comforting to know I'm not alone in that. I also like that there are a few community programs and local organizations that offer things like job training or financial assistance, even if I haven't taken full advantage of them yet. But there are definitely challenges too. The cost of living has gone up a lot in the past few years, and even though I make a decent wage at the bookstore, it's hard to save much. I sometimes feel like I'm just barely keeping my head above water, and that can be really exhausting. Still, I try to focus on the good things—like the fact that I have a roof over my head, a job I can rely on, and people who care about me. I guess I'm learning to be grateful for the little things, even when life feels heavy.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my roots and current environment shape who I am. Talking about my mom, dad, and sister reminded me of the strength and sacrifices that have defined my life so far. Even though my dad isn't here anymore, his memory still influences me, and I carry his work ethic with me every day. My mom's push for me to keep learning, even when I wasn't sure where I was going, has stayed with me. My sister's success in Atlanta gives me hope that I can also find my own path someday. As for my neighborhood in Birmingham, it's not perfect, but it feels like a place where I can belong and keep moving forward. The sense of community here is something I didn't expect, and it's comforting to know I'm not alone in my struggles. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm grateful for the support I have and the small but meaningful things that keep me going.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Lauren Richardson: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are still little variations depending on what's going on at work or how I'm feeling. I start my day early, usually around 6:30 a.m., because I need to get to the bookstore by 8. My job is pretty steady—helping customers, restocking shelves, and sometimes doing inventory. I enjoy the routine of it, even if it's not the most exciting thing in the world. On weekends, I try to take it easy, but I often end up running errands or helping my mom with something. I've been trying to get back into reading more, so I'll usually spend an hour or two on the weekends with a book. I also like to take walks in the neighborhood or visit the community center if I have time. It's not much, but it's enough to keep me grounded. I guess the biggest thing that varies is how much I'm thinking about the future—some days I feel more motivated to save up for school, and other days I just want to focus on the present and enjoy the little things I have.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Lauren Richardson: I work full-time at a bookstore downtown, mostly in the mornings from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. It's a pretty steady job, and I've been there for almost three years now. The hours are good because they leave me with the evenings and weekends free, which I try to use for reading, helping my mom out, or just relaxing. I also do some freelance writing on the side, mostly for local blogs or community newsletters. It's not a lot of money, but it helps me keep my creative side alive and gives me a little extra income. I've been thinking about taking some online courses in writing or marketing to see if I can turn that into something more serious. I guess I'm trying to keep my options open, even if I'm not sure where I'm headed yet.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Lauren Richardson: I also have a routine of helping my mom with her grading and lesson planning a few times a week, especially on weekends when she's overwhelmed with work. She's a high school teacher, and it's a lot for her to handle on her own. It feels good to support her in that way, even if it's just small things like organizing her papers or helping her prepare materials. I also try to set aside time each week to check in with my sister, even if it's just a quick call. She's always encouraging me to think about my future, and I guess that keeps me from getting too stuck in my current situation. On the flip side, I do have moments where I feel like I'm just going through the motions—like I'm working hard but not really moving forward. I think that's why I've been trying to get back into writing, because it's the one thing that still feels like it connects me to who I used to be, before I got caught up in all the responsibilities.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Lauren Richardson: One of the biggest changes to my daily routine has been starting to take online courses in creative writing. I signed up for a few through a community college program, and I'm taking them in the evenings after work. It's been challenging to balance everything, but I'm trying to make it work. I've also started setting aside specific times each week to think about my long-term goals, which I never really did before. It's strange how much just having that structure has helped me feel more in control of my life. I still have a lot of uncertainty, but I think these small steps are helping me move forward in a way I didn't expect.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Lauren Richardson: I don't have children yet, but I think about what it would be like if I did. I imagine a typical weekday for them would start early, maybe around 7 a.m., with breakfast and getting ready for school. They'd probably go to a local public school, like the one my sister went to, and have a pretty standard routine—classes from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., followed by some kind of after-school activity. I hope they'd have the chance to do something they're passionate about, like art or sports, just like my sister did with marketing. I know it's a ways off, but I want to be there for them, to support them the way my mom supported me. It's hard to imagine, but I think having kids would push me to finally take that next step toward something more, even if I'm not sure what that is yet.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my family and daily life shape the way I see myself and my future. Talking about my family reminded me of the strength and sacrifices that have defined my life so far, and how much I owe to my mom, dad, and sister. Even though my dad isn't here anymore, his work ethic still influences me every day, and my mom's encouragement to keep learning has stayed with me. My sister's success in Atlanta gives me hope that I can also find my own path someday. As for my neighborhood in Birmingham, it's not perfect, but it feels like a place where I can belong and keep moving forward. The sense of community here is something I didn't expect, and it's comforting to know I'm not alone in my struggles. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm grateful for the support I have and the small but meaningful things that keep me going. Living here has its ups and downs, but I try to focus on the good things—like having a roof over my head, a job I can rely on, and people who care about me. I'm learning to be grateful for the little things, even when life feels heavy. My daily routine has been pretty consistent, but I've been making some small changes, like taking online courses in creative writing and setting aside time to think about my long-term goals. These steps, though small, are helping me feel more in control of my life and more hopeful about the future.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Lauren Richardson: My health has been pretty stable overall, though I've had my share of stress-related issues over the years. I used to get really bad migraines, especially during my late teens when I was working full-time and trying to juggle everything else. I think the constant pressure of making ends meet and not having a clear path forward took a toll on me. I started seeing a doctor about it a few years back, and they recommended some lifestyle changes—like getting more sleep, eating better, and finding ways to manage stress. I've been trying to stick with that, and it's helped a lot. I also started going to the community center for some low-impact exercise classes, which I really enjoy. It's not just about staying healthy—it's about feeling more balanced and in control of my life. I know I'm not perfect at it, but I'm making an effort, and that's something I can be proud of.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Lauren Richardson: Staying healthy is easier when I have a routine, like going to the community center for exercise or making sure I eat something decent for breakfast. But it's hard when I'm feeling overwhelmed or when work is really busy. I'll skip meals or stay up too late, and that just makes everything worse. I know I need to take care of myself, but sometimes it feels like the last thing I can focus on. It's a constant battle, but I'm learning that even small things—like taking a walk or drinking more water—can make a difference. I guess the hardest part is remembering to prioritize my health when everything else feels so heavy.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Lauren Richardson: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some chronic back pain that I didn't realize was connected to the long hours I've spent standing at work. I used to ignore it, thinking it was just part of the job, but it started getting worse, especially after I started taking those online courses and staying up late to finish assignments. I finally went to the doctor, and they said it's probably from poor posture and muscle strain over time. They gave me some physical therapy exercises and recommended I take more breaks during the day. It's been a bit of a struggle to adjust, but I'm slowly getting better. I also had a minor flare-up of my migraines last winter, which was tough because I was already dealing with the back pain. It reminded me how important it is to take care of myself, even when life feels overwhelming. I'm still working on it, but I'm trying to be more proactive now.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Lauren Richardson: Honestly, the health issues have made things a little harder, especially with work. I've had days where the back pain was so bad that I had to take a break in the middle of my shift, which is something I never used to do. It's embarrassing, but I've learned that I can't push through everything just because I feel like I have to. The migraines have also made it tough to focus on my online courses, especially when they come on suddenly and leave me feeling drained. I know I need to take things slower, but it's hard when you're used to being the one who takes care of everyone else. Still, I'm trying to be more mindful of my body and not ignore the signals it's giving me. I guess it's another reminder that I need to take care of myself if I want to keep going forward.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Lauren Richardson: Over the past year, I've been going through a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, I feel like I'm finally starting to take some steps toward the future I used to dream about, even if it's slow. Taking those online writing courses has been a big part of that—it's like I'm reconnecting with a part of myself I thought I'd lost. But on the other hand, there are days when I feel stuck, like I'm just going through the motions. The back pain and migraines have made it harder to focus, and I've had to learn how to be more patient with myself. I've also been thinking a lot about my family, especially my mom and sister. They've always been my biggest supporters, and I'm grateful for that. I know I haven't made as much progress as I'd like, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and not let the weight of everything hold me back. I guess I'm just learning that growth doesn't always happen all at once—it's more like taking small steps every day, even when you don't see the destination yet.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily life and health have shaped my sense of self and my ability to move forward. Talking about my recent changes, like taking online writing courses and setting aside time for long-term goals, reminded me that even small steps can make a difference. It also made me realize how much I've been neglecting my health over the years—whether it was pushing through migraines or ignoring back pain because I felt like I had to be strong for everyone else. I've always thought of myself as someone who puts others first, but I'm starting to see that taking care of myself isn't selfish—it's necessary. I've been trying to be more mindful of my body and my limits, and while it's still a work in progress, I feel like I'm finally learning to listen to myself. These questions made me think about how much I've grown, even if it's not in the way I originally imagined. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm grateful for the support I have and the small but meaningful changes I'm making in my life.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Lauren Richardson: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, especially in the past few years. It's not something I used to talk about, but I've started to realize how much it's affected me. There are days when I feel like I'm carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders—my job, my family, my future, and even the small things like paying rent or eating well. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder, everything would get better. But lately, I've been learning that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and that it's not a sign of weakness. I've started seeing a therapist through a community program, and it's been really helpful. Talking about my thoughts and feelings has made me feel less alone, even if I'm not sure where I'm going yet. I still have bad days, but I'm trying to be more honest with myself and with the people who care about me. It's not easy, but I think it's the first step toward something better.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Lauren Richardson: My family has been through a lot too, especially my mom. She's always been the strong one, but I can tell she's been carrying a lot of stress lately. She works long hours as a teacher, and I know she worries about me—not just because I haven't gone to college, but because she wants the best for me. She never says it out loud, but I can see it in the way she looks at me sometimes, like she's waiting for me to take that next step. My sister, on the other hand, has been more open about her own struggles. She's been working hard in Atlanta, but she's also dealing with the pressure of trying to build a life on her own. We talk a lot about it, and I think she sees me as someone who's still figuring things out, which is both comforting and a little frustrating. My dad's passing still affects us all, even though it's been a few years now. He was the one who always made me feel like I could do anything, and I think my mom and I both miss that. But even with all the challenges, I feel like we're all trying to support each other in our own ways. It's not perfect, but I think that's what family is—imperfect, but always there.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Lauren Richardson: I think religion has always been more of a background presence in my life rather than something I actively engage with. When I was younger, I was raised Protestant, like most of the people in my community, and I went to church with my family on Sundays. It wasn't something I questioned much back then—it was just part of the rhythm of life. But as I got older, especially after my dad passed away, I started thinking more about what it all meant. I don't know if I'd call myself spiritual, but I do believe in something bigger than myself. I think about the people who have supported me, the small moments of kindness, and how even in the hardest times, there's a kind of quiet strength that keeps you going. I don't go to church anymore, and I don't really follow any specific religious practices, but I still find comfort in knowing that I'm not alone in this life. I guess I see it more as a personal belief in connection and resilience rather than a formal religion.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Lauren Richardson: I don't use social media too much, honestly. I have a Facebook account mostly to stay in touch with family and a few old friends, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or engaging with posts. I think it's more of a passive thing for me—like, I'll check it once in a while to see what's going on with my mom or my sister, or if someone from high school is posting something. I don't really use Instagram or Twitter, and I've never been into TikTok or anything like that. I guess I just don't feel the need to be constantly connected to the wider world that way. There's something about it that feels overwhelming, like there's so much noise and comparison, and I don't want to get caught up in that. I prefer keeping things simple—texting my friends, calling my mom, or just being present in the moment. I know it's not the same as what a lot of people do, but it works for me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Lauren Richardson: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really used social media for support, even when things were tough. I know a lot of people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but I've always been more of a private person. I don't want to burden others with my problems, and I also don't want to compare myself to what I see on those platforms. There's something about seeing everyone else's highlight reels that just makes me feel worse about my own situation. I've tried reaching out to friends through messages or calls when I needed something, and I think that's been enough for me. I don't know if I'd ever feel comfortable asking for help in a public way, but I'm learning that it's okay to ask for support, even if it's just from the people I already know and trust.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my chronic back pain and migraines reminded me of how much I've been pushing through without really taking care of myself. It's not just about the physical discomfort—it's also about the emotional weight of feeling like I have to be strong for everyone else, even when I'm struggling. Learning that I've been dealing with anxiety more than I realized was a wake-up call. I used to think I could handle everything on my own, but now I see that it's okay to ask for help and to take things slower. It's also been eye-opening to talk about how my family has been affected by these challenges. My mom has always been the strong one, but I can see the stress she's been carrying, and my sister has been dealing with her own pressures in Atlanta. It's comforting to know we're all trying to support each other, even if we're not perfect at it. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm starting to understand that taking care of myself isn't a weakness—it's a necessary step toward moving forward.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Lauren Richardson: I think my stress levels have been pretty consistent, but I've been trying to develop better coping strategies. I used to deal with everything on my own—pushing through the pain, the worry, the uncertainty—because I didn't want to burden anyone else. But lately, I've been learning that it's okay to slow down and take a breath. I've started journaling more, which helps me process my thoughts, and I've been trying to be more open with my mom and sister about how I'm feeling. It's not always easy, but talking about it makes me feel less alone. I've also been finding small ways to take care of myself, like going for walks when I feel overwhelmed or just sitting quietly with a cup of tea and letting my mind rest. I know I'm not perfect at it, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and not let the weight of everything hold me back. It's a work in progress, but I think these little changes are helping me feel more grounded, even if I'm still figuring things out.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Lauren Richardson: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and utilities. Rent for my one-bedroom apartment in Birmingham came out to around $850, which is a chunk of my paycheck. Groceries were another big one—since I work full-time and help my mom out sometimes, I try to keep meals simple but nutritious. I spent about $300 on food, and that includes snacks and drinks for work. Utilities, like electricity and water, ran me around $150, and I also had to budget for my phone bill and internet, which together were about $80. I also set aside some money for my online writing courses, which cost about $100 a month. The rest of my income goes toward savings, but it's not much—maybe $100 or so. It's tight, but I try to be careful with every dollar. I know it's not much, but it's enough to keep me going, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Lauren Richardson: My household spending last month was pretty much the same as usual, though there were a few small fluctuations. I live alone now, so my expenses are just my own, but I still help my mom out with groceries and utilities sometimes. She's on a fixed income as a teacher, so even though she makes a decent salary, it's not always enough to cover everything. I usually set aside about $50 each month to help her with her bills, and that's something I've been doing for a while now. Other than that, my spending stays pretty consistent—rent, groceries, utilities, internet, and the writing courses. I try to be careful with my money because I know how tight things can get, especially with the rising costs of living in Birmingham. I don't usually splurge on anything, but I do treat myself to a coffee or a small meal out once in a while, just to feel a little normal. It's not much, but it helps me feel like I'm still living, not just surviving.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Lauren Richardson: I rent my home, actually. I live in a small one-bedroom apartment near downtown Birmingham. It's not much, but it's affordable and convenient since my job at the bookstore is just a short walk away. Renting has always been the way to go for me, especially since I'm still figuring out my long-term plans. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon—there's just too much uncertainty about my future. Plus, with the way the housing market is, I don't think I could afford anything right now, even if I wanted to. Renting gives me the flexibility to move if I need to, which is something I value, even if it means I never really get to put down roots in one place.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Lauren Richardson: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and some unexpected expenses. For example, during the winter, my utility bills went up because I was using more electricity for heating, and I had to buy a new blanket for my apartment since the old one was worn out. I also had to replace my laptop last spring because the one I was using for my online writing courses started acting up, and I couldn't afford to keep waiting for repairs. That was a big hit to my budget, but I managed to get a used one through a community buy-and-sell group, which saved me some money. Then there were the holidays—Christmas was tough because I wanted to give my mom and sister something nice, even if it was just a small gift. I ended up buying them both books, which wasn't too expensive, but it still felt like a lot at the time. I also had to budget for a few unexpected things, like a new pair of shoes for work and some medication for my back pain. It's been a bit of a rollercoaster, but I've learned to be more flexible with my money and to look for ways to save whenever I can, like buying groceries in bulk or using coupons when I shop. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be more mindful of how I spend, even if it's just small things.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my family and my approach to social media have shaped my emotional well-being. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've been through, especially my mom, who's always been the strong one, and my sister, who's forging her own path in Atlanta. It's comforting to know we're all trying to support each other, even if we're not perfect at it. I also reflected on how I don't use social media much, which has been both a blessing and a limitation. I don't feel the need to be constantly connected, and I prefer keeping things simple with texts and calls. But I also realize that I could be more open about my struggles, even if it's just with the people I already know and trust. It's not about being on social media—it's about finding ways to ask for help and not carry everything alone. I'm still learning that it's okay to be vulnerable, even if it doesn't feel natural at first.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Lauren Richardson: I do have a savings account, though it's not very big. I try to set aside whatever I can each month, even if it's just a few dollars. It's more of a habit now—like, whenever I get paid, I automatically transfer a small amount to savings before I start spending on anything else. I know it's not much, but it gives me a sense of security, even if it's just a little. I used to think saving wasn't important because I didn't see a future where I'd need it, but now I realize that having even a small emergency fund can make a big difference. I also keep a jar at home for smaller, more immediate savings—like for unexpected expenses or when I want to buy something I really need but can't afford right away. It's not perfect, and I'm still learning how to manage money better, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it now. I guess saving isn't about having a lot—it's about being prepared for whatever comes next, even if I don't know what that is yet.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Lauren Richardson: For me, saving has mostly been about having a rainy day fund, even if it's just a small one. I don't see myself buying a home anytime soon, so I haven't really focused on saving for that. Instead, I've been trying to build up something that can help me if I need to cover unexpected expenses, like a medical bill or a sudden repair for my apartment. I know it's not much—maybe a couple hundred dollars at most—but it gives me some peace of mind. I also try to save a little for when I finally decide to go back to school, even if I don't know when that will be. It's not about having a lot; it's about being ready for whatever comes next, even if I don't have all the answers yet.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Lauren Richardson: My occupation is working full-time at a bookstore downtown, where I help customers find books, restock shelves, and sometimes assist with inventory management. The most important part of my job is the routine—it gives me structure and a sense of purpose, even if it's not the most exciting work. I also do some freelance writing on the side, mostly for local blogs or community newsletters, which allows me to keep my creative side alive. It's not a lot of money, but it helps me feel connected to something bigger than just the daily grind. I think the most important activities are the ones that keep me grounded, like interacting with customers who come in looking for recommendations or just wanting to chat. Those moments remind me that even in a small job, there's value in what I do. I also enjoy the quiet of the bookstore—it's a place where I can lose myself in stories, and that's something I really appreciate.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Lauren Richardson: I usually work around 40 hours a week at the bookstore, which is pretty standard for a full-time position. I'm on the morning shift, from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., Monday through Friday, and I get weekends off. That gives me some time to rest and catch up on things, though I often end up helping my mom with grading or doing some freelance writing in the evenings. It's not always easy balancing work with everything else, but I've learned to make the most of the time I have. I think the hours are manageable, and I'm grateful for the stability it provides, even if it doesn't always feel like it's leading me somewhere specific.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Lauren Richardson: I did have a few other jobs or side gigs over the years, especially when I was first starting out. After high school, I worked part-time at the bookstore, but I also did some babysitting for neighbors and even worked at a local café on weekends. It wasn't much, but it helped me make ends meet while I was still figuring things out. A few years ago, I started doing some freelance writing on the side, which has become more consistent now. I write for local blogs, community newsletters, and sometimes even do small content creation for small businesses. It's not a full-time job, but it gives me a little extra income and keeps me connected to my passion for writing. I also used to work evenings at a library during the school year, helping with after-school programs for kids. That was a really rewarding experience, even if it was just a few hours a week. I think having multiple jobs or side gigs has been a way for me to stay busy, earn a little more, and keep my options open. It's not always easy juggling everything, but I've learned to make it work, even if it means sacrificing some free time or rest.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress, emotional coping strategies, and financial situation have shaped my daily life and sense of self. Talking about my stress levels and the ways I've been trying to manage them reminded me of how much I've been holding everything in for so long. I used to think I had to be strong for everyone else, but now I'm starting to see that taking a moment to breathe or journaling my thoughts is just as important as working hard. It's also been eye-opening to think about how my financial situation affects my mental health—knowing that every dollar I spend is carefully considered, and that I'm constantly balancing between saving, paying bills, and trying to move forward with my goals. I've always thought of myself as someone who puts others first, but I'm learning that taking care of myself isn't a weakness—it's necessary for me to keep going. These questions made me realize that even small changes, like being more open with my family or finding ways to take care of my body, can make a big difference in how I feel about my life and future.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Lauren Richardson: My household income last month was around $2,200, mostly from my job at the bookstore. I make about $12 an hour, and with 40 hours a week, that adds up to roughly $1,920 before taxes. Then I get an extra $200 or so from my freelance writing gigs, which helps cover some of the smaller expenses. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep me afloat, especially since I'm not paying for a lot of the things my mom used to cover when I was younger. I know it's not much compared to what other people make, but I'm trying to be grateful for what I have. I also try to budget carefully, because I know how quickly things can get out of hand if I'm not careful. It's a tight balance, but I'm learning to be more mindful of every dollar I spend.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Lauren Richardson: I've been working at the bookstore for almost three years now, and it's become a pretty big part of my life. The benefits aren't anything fancy—there's no health insurance or paid vacation days, just the basics like sick leave and some holiday bonuses. I don't mind it too much because I've always been the type to work hard and not expect too much in return. Still, it's something I've thought about lately, especially with the back pain and migraines I've been dealing with. I know a lot of people in my position would be lucky to have even that, but I also know that it's not enough to really take care of myself long-term. That's why I've been trying to build up some savings and look into other opportunities, like the community college courses I'm taking. I guess I'm just trying to find a way to keep moving forward, even if it's not the most comfortable path.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Lauren Richardson: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. I get along well with my coworkers—they're all friendly and we often joke around, especially during slow days. We've been through a lot together, like the time the store had to close early because of a storm, and we all ended up staying late to help clean up. My manager is fair, though not always the easiest to talk to. She's pretty strict about following procedures, which I understand because the store runs on a tight schedule. I respect her for that, even if I don't always agree with her decisions. There have been times when I felt like I wasn't getting the recognition I deserved, but I've learned to focus on what I can control. I think the most important thing is that I feel respected and valued here, even if it's not always in the way I'd like. I know I'm not the most ambitious person, but I take pride in doing my job well and being a reliable part of the team.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Lauren Richardson: My work schedule is pretty predictable, which is something I actually appreciate. I work the same hours every week—8 a.m. to 4 p.m., Monday through Friday—so I can plan my days around that. It gives me a sense of stability, especially with everything else going on in my life. That said, there are times when things get a little more flexible. For example, if there's a holiday or a special event, the store might close early or have a different schedule, and I've had to adjust a bit then. But for the most part, I know what to expect, which helps me manage my time better. I also like that I can take some time off on the weekends, even if I don't always use it for anything exciting. It's just nice to have that structure, especially when the rest of my life feels so uncertain.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Lauren Richardson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely tight. I know I'm not struggling in the way some people do, but I also know I'm not in a position to take big risks or make sudden changes. Every dollar I earn feels like it's going toward something I need—rent, groceries, utilities, or my online courses. I don't have much left over, and that can be frustrating because I want to save more, or maybe even take a class that costs more than what I can afford right now. But I also know that I'm not alone in this. A lot of people around me are in the same boat, trying to make ends meet while still holding on to their dreams. I guess I'm trying to be patient with myself and not get too discouraged. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I'm still moving forward, even if it's just a little at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me think a lot about how my financial situation and work life have shaped my sense of stability and uncertainty. Talking about how my bills fluctuate over the year reminded me of the small, everyday struggles—like paying for heating in the winter or replacing a worn-out laptop. It's easy to feel like I'm just barely keeping up, but I've learned to be more flexible with my money and find ways to save, even if it's just a little at a time. Reflecting on my occupation and work hours made me appreciate the structure my job provides, even if it's not the most exciting or well-paying. I know I'm not in a position to take big risks, but I'm still trying to move forward, one step at a time. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be grateful for what I have and to keep working toward something better, even if I don't know exactly what that looks like yet.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Lauren Richardson: Yes, my mom worked for pay while I was growing up, and she worked pretty much every year since I was a kid. She started as a substitute teacher before she went back to school for her bachelor's degree, and after she finished, she became a full-time high school teacher. It wasn't easy—she had to juggle school, work, and taking care of me and my dad, who wasn't always around because he was working multiple jobs to support us. I remember her staying up late grading papers or planning lessons, and I always felt bad that she had to do so much. But she never complained, and she always made sure I had what I needed. I think that's why I feel so strongly about helping her out now, even if it's just with grading or lesson planning. She taught me that hard work pays off, even if it doesn't always feel fair at the time.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Lauren Richardson: My mom's job was teaching high school, and it was more than just standing in front of a classroom. She had to plan every lesson, grade papers, meet with students and parents, and even take on extra responsibilities when the school needed it. She was always the one who stayed late, whether it was to help a student who was struggling or to prepare for the next day's classes. I remember seeing her stress when she had to balance her job with her own education, and I think that's why she always pushed me to keep learning, even when I wasn't sure where I was going. She never had a lot of money, but she always made sure that I had the tools I needed to succeed. I think that's why I feel so strongly about helping her out now—because she gave me everything she could, and I want to pay that forward in my own way.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Lauren Richardson: My mom worked for the local public school system, specifically at a high school in the same town where I grew up. It was a pretty traditional school, not too different from the ones you see in most small towns. She was a history teacher, which I always thought was really cool because she had this way of making the past feel alive. She didn't just read from a textbook—she told stories, brought in artifacts, and made sure her students could connect with the material. But her job wasn't just about teaching. She had to manage a classroom of teenagers, deal with administrative tasks, and sometimes even take on extra duties like advising student clubs or organizing school events. I remember seeing her stress when she had to balance all of that with her own education, and I think that's why she always pushed me to keep learning, even when I wasn't sure where I was going. She never had a lot of money, but she always made sure that I had the tools I needed to succeed. I think that's why I feel so strongly about helping her out now—because she gave me everything she could, and I want to pay that forward in my own way.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Lauren Richardson: I hope that in a few years, I'm still here, still working hard, but maybe with a little more direction and purpose. I don't know exactly what that looks like yet—whether it's going back to school for writing, finding a better job, or even something completely different. I just hope I'm not stuck in the same place I am now, feeling like I'm just going through the motions. I hope I've made some progress, even if it's small, and that I'm finally taking better care of myself—physically and emotionally. I hope my mom is proud of me, and that I'm able to support her in the way she supported me. I also hope that I've found the courage to take that next step, whatever it is, and that I'm not still wondering what could have been. I think the most important thing is that I'm still here, still trying, and still believing that things can get better—no matter how slow the progress feels.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Lauren Richardson: What I value the most in my life is connection—connection with my family, with the people who understand what it's like to work hard and still feel like you're not quite where you want to be. I value the little moments, like my mom calling me just to check in, or my sister sharing a story from Atlanta, or even the quiet moments at the bookstore when I can lose myself in a book. I value the strength it takes to keep going, even when things feel heavy. I value the fact that I'm still here, still trying, and still holding on to the hope that one day I'll find my way. I think that's what keeps me going—the belief that even if I don't have all the answers now, I'm still moving forward, one step at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my work life and financial situation shape my sense of stability and uncertainty. Talking about my household income and the challenges of making ends meet reminded me of how much I've been holding everything together, even when it feels like I'm just barely keeping up. It also made me think about my job at the bookstore—how it's been a steady part of my life, even if it's not the most exciting or well-paying. I realized that while I may not have many benefits or opportunities for advancement, I still take pride in doing my job well and being a reliable part of the team. It's not always easy to feel like I'm in a place where I can grow, but I'm learning to be grateful for the small things, like the structure my job provides and the support I have from my coworkers. These questions also made me think about how much I want to move forward, even if I don't know exactly where that path will take me. I know I'm not in a position to take big risks, but I'm still trying to find ways to build a better future, one step at a time.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, one that has brought back so many memories and emotions I hadn't thought about in a while. It's strange how talking about my childhood, my family, my struggles, and my small victories has made me feel both nostalgic and hopeful. I never really thought about how much my mom's sacrifices shaped who I am, or how my choice to put my family first at 19 still echoes in my life today. It's also made me realize how much I've been holding back, not just from opportunities but from my own sense of self. I've always been the quiet one, the one who puts others first, but I'm starting to see that I need to prioritize myself too. This interview has reminded me that even though my life hasn't gone the way I originally imagined, I'm still moving forward, one small step at a time. I'm still working, still learning, still trying to find my way, and I think that's what matters most. I may not have all the answers yet, but I'm grateful for the support I have and the strength I've found within myself. I hope that in the future, I can look back on this moment and see how far I've come, even if it's not in the way I expected.
